modules.description: This module implements arithmetic operations on timespec values, which represent time intervals with second and nanosecond components. It supports addition, subtraction, and comparison of timespec values, as well as direct modification by seconds or nanoseconds. Use cases include precise time interval calculations, such as measuring execution durations or scheduling events with nanosecond resolution.

This module defines a data structure for specifying interval timers, with operations to set and retrieve the interval and initial value as `Timespec.t` values. It works with timer specifications that include both a repetition interval and a first-fire time. Concrete use cases include configuring periodic timers in system-level code, such as setting up signals at fixed intervals or scheduling timed events.

This module defines a data structure representing a broken-down time value with fields for seconds, minutes, hours, and other date components. It provides a `create` function to construct valid time values from individual components and a `compare` function to order time values based on year, month, day, and time fields. It is used to represent and compare specific points in time in a structured, calendar-based format.

This module represents time values in seconds and microseconds, supporting arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, and comparisons. It provides functions to create, manipulate, and convert time intervals, ensuring normalized results. Use it to measure durations, schedule events with microsecond precision, or compute time differences in system-level operations.

This module handles precise time representations and operations using `Timespec`, `Timeval`, `Tm`, and `Itimerspec` structures. It supports arithmetic, comparison, and normalization operations tailored for system-level timing tasks like interval measurement, event scheduling, and calendar-based time comparisons. Specific applications include high-resolution timing measurements, timer configuration with nanosecond or microsecond precision, and structured time value manipulation.
